title: Home | L'Hexagone

on-this-day-events.text: On this day in 1909, Joan of Arc was beatified by the Catholic Church. Beatification is the process of recognising someone as a blessed or holy person, and it’s a step towards becoming a saint. Joan of Arc, a young French woman who led troops during the Hundred Years' War, was captured and executed at 19. Her bravery and faith inspired many, and after her death, she was remembered as a national hero. Her beatification in 1909 recognised her as a holy figure and a martyr for her faith, paving the way for her canonisation as a saint in 1920.

On this day in 1906, Pierre Curie, a pioneering French physicist renowned for his work on radioactivity, tragically died in a street accident in Paris. He was the husband of Marie Curie, and together they were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1903 for their groundbreaking research on radioactivity. Their discoveries laid the foundation for significant advancements in science and medicine, including cancer treatment and nuclear energy.​

On this day in 1848, the first elections for the French National Assembly were held under the newly formed Second Republic. These elections marked an important moment in French history, as they were the first time that all adult men in France had the right to vote, following the abolition of the monarchy. This event was a key step in the development of democratic principles in France.

On this day in 1792, the First French Republic officially adopted the Revolutionary Calendar, which was used in France from 1793 to 1805. The year began with the autumn equinox, and months were renamed after natural features, such as 'Vendémiaire' (harvest month) and 'Brumaire' (fog month). This calendar was used as a symbol of the break from traditional monarchy and the desire to mark the new era of the Republic. It was eventually abandoned in 1805.

On this day in 1769, Madame du Barry became the official mistress of King Louis XV of France. She had previously been a courtesan, and her rise to prominence marked a significant shift in the French court's dynamics. Her relationship with the king was controversial, as she was seen by some as a symbol of the moral decline of the monarchy. Despite this, Madame du Barry became an influential figure, and her status as the king’s official mistress made her one of the most powerful women in France at the time.

On this day in 711, following the death of his father, Childebert III, Dagobert III ascended to the throne as King of the Franks. At approximately 12 years old, his reign was largely symbolic, with real power exercised by Pippin of Herstal, the Mayor of the Palace. This period exemplifies the declining authority of Merovingian monarchs and the increasing influence of mayors of the palace. Dagobert III's reign set the stage for the eventual rise of the Carolingian dynasty, which would reshape the political landscape of medieval France.

On this day in 1792, the revolutionary anthem "La Marseillaise" was first performed in Paris. Composed by Claude Joseph Rouget de Lisle, the song was originally titled "Chant de guerre pour l'Armée du Rhin" ("War Song for the Army of the Rhine"). It quickly gained popularity and became a symbol of the French Revolution. "La Marseillaise" was adopted as the national anthem of France in 1795.

On this day in 1792, the guillotine was used for the first time in France to execute Nicolas Jacques Pelletier, a convicted highwayman. The execution took place in Paris, marking the introduction of this device as the standard method of capital punishment. The guillotine was adopted during the French Revolution as a more humane and egalitarian means of execution, replacing previous methods that varied by social class. Its use became a symbol of the revolutionary ideals of equality and justice.

On this day in 1905, Jean Vigo was born in Paris, France. Despite a tragically short career, Vigo left an indelible mark on French cinema through his innovative and poetic filmmaking. His works, including À propos de Nice (1930), Zéro de conduite (1933), and L'Atalante (1934), blended realism with surrealism and anarchic themes, challenging traditional cinematic norms and cementing his legacy as a pivotal figure in French cultural history.

On this day in 1932, Anouk Aimée was born in Paris as Nicole Françoise Florence Dreyfus. Over a career spanning more than seven decades, she became one of France's most celebrated actresses, known for her enigmatic screen presence and collaborations with renowned directors. Her performances in films such as La Dolce Vita (1960), Lola (1961), and A Man and a Woman (1966) earned her international acclaim, including a Golden Globe Award and an Academy Award nomination.

On this day in 1988, Jonathan Biabiany was born in Paris, France. Known for his exceptional speed and agility on the field, Biabiany has made a name for himself as a dynamic right winger. His professional career includes notable stints with clubs such as Inter Milan and Parma, where he contributed significantly to their attacks.

On this day in 1930, Jean Rochefort was born in Paris, France. Renowned for his distinctive moustache and expressive performances, Rochefort became one of France's most beloved actors. His versatile career spanned over five decades, featuring notable roles in films such as Le Mari de la coiffeuse, Ridicule and Le Crabe-Tambour, for which he received the César Award for Best Actor.

On this day in 1952, Jacques Audiard was born in Paris, France. He is one of the most celebrated French filmmakers, known for his compelling storytelling and innovative direction. Audiard has received numerous accolades, including an Academy Award, two BAFTA Awards, and thirteen César Awards—the most individual wins in the history of the César Awards. His notable films include The Beat That My Heart Skipped (2005), A Prophet (2009), Dheepan (2015), and Emilia Pérez (2024).

On this day in 1903, the first Tour de France bicycle race began in the village of Montgeron. The race finished on the edge of Paris at Ville d'Avray and was won by Italian cyclist Maurice Garin.

Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur.
On this day in 1904, Frenchman Louis Rigolly became the first man to break the 100mph (161km/h) barrier on land, driving a Gobron Brillié in Ostend, Belgium.
On this day in 1832, Napoleon II, who was disputedly the Emperor of France for a few weeks in 1815, died of tuberculosis.
On this day in 1931, France announced that, due to the Great Depression, they couldn't afford to send a team to the 1932 Los Angeles Olympics. They did, however, eventually manage to send a team.
On this day in 1967, French president Charles de Gaulle expressed his support towards Quebec by saying "Vive le Québec libre ! Long live free Quebec!"
On this day in 1909, Frenchman Louis Blériot made the first aeroplane flight across the English Channel.
On this day in 1985, former Arsenal, Manchester City and AS Cannes left back Gaël Clichy was born in Toulouse.

On this day in 1824, Alexandre Dumas fils, son of the author of novels such as The Three Musketeers and The Count of Monte-Cristo, was born. Dumas fils himself was an author and playwright, with his most famous work coming in the form of the romantic novel La Dame aux Camélias, which was adapted into Verdi's 1853 opera La Traviata.
On this day in 1655, famous French novelist and playwright Cyrano de Bergerac died at the age of 36. The exact details of his death are not conclusive.

On this day in 1818, French physicist Augustin Fresnel submitted his prizewinning Memoir on the Diffraction of Light, which precisely accounted for the limited extent to which light spreads into shadows. This demolished the oldest objection to the wave theory of light.

On this day in 1996, French-American actress Claudette Colbert died at the age of 92, likely due to a stroke. Colbert is most well known for It Happened One Night (1934), for which she won a Best Actress Oscar.

On this day in 2017, French actress Jeanne Moreau died at the age of 89. Moreau starred in Elevator to the Gallows (1958) and Seven Days... Seven Nights (1960), for which she won the Cannes Film Festival Award for Best Actress. She also featured prominently in La Notte (1961) and Jules et Jim (1962), and iconic director Orson Welles called her the "greatest actress in the world".
On this day in 1919, the Rodin Museum opened in Paris in the Hôtel Biron, exhibiting almost 300 works left by the state by the French sculptor Auguste Rodin.
On this day in 1868, French astronomer Pierre Janssen discovered a gaseous element while observing a solar eclipse, which would later be named Helium.
On this day in 1715, King Louis XIV died after a reign of 72 years. This remains the longest reign of any major European monarch.
On this day in 1792, the Hope Diamond was stolen along with other French crown jewels. Six men broke into the Garde-Meuble where the jewels were stored.

spotlights.title: Plan Your Filming Location Tour Now!

home-heading-1: L'Hexagone- the tourism website that connects you with France!
home-description-1: Our name comes from the nickname that French locals give to Metropolitan France, as it resembles the shape of a hexagon. Our goal is to provide users with an enjoyable, interactive experience, providing connections between France and the user's own country, as well as opportunities to engage with French culture without difficulty.
home-description-2: In 2016, France restructured its regional map, reducing the number of metropolitan regions from 22 to 13. This reform merged several existing regions to create larger administrative areas with more resources and stronger political influence. The aim was to simplify governance and promote regional development. While the names and borders changed for many parts of mainland France, Corsica remained unchanged, and the five overseas regions (Guadeloupe, Martinique, French Guiana, Réunion, Mayotte) kept their separate identities. Today, each region plays a key role in areas like education, transport and economic planning.
